author: glacier
text:
Thank you for a lovely piece. 
I am aware of these "artist expeditions" - and I have much hope for them. Because we scientists tend to report back the changes we observe - and thus forget (or with few exceptions, are not able) to report the magnificence which is up there. To be lost. 
I do not quite know how to say the next. We got report for another tourist cruice - ending up with the killing of a polar bear. 
In a way I wish everyone the chance to go and see the beauty of pristine nature - even as it decays under our human actions. But on the other hand, the "last chance to see" tourism is also the excess lives we live that is a major reason for the polar bears now having to hunt on land instead on the sea-ice based seal hunting they adapted to. 
It is a double slam that we first melt the sea-ice due to our consumption at home, then see the potential for cruise-ship holidays on the recently de-iced Ocean (polar bear hunting ground) - then taking the light boats to shore - just to be attacked by starving land-locked polar bear - ending with shooting it to death to defend ourselves from the dangers of nature. 
If there is a heart-breaking story - it is this one. Also because it is so universal. 
I would also like to say that after the good walk-through of the history (up to mining) - Svalbard is now a international hub for Arctic research and education. Not only on ground monitoring, but also for global remote sensing data. 
And as architect, I would have liked to read about your take on the classical methods used even for modern buildings (like the University building) - with wood (not concrete) driven down into the permafrost as the most stable fundament). 
And the fact that the little town of Spitsbergen now has pretty much it's entire planning regime being rewritten. 
... Just having written this I notice my own professional bias and genes kicking in, and pretty much destroying what I opened with. 
Us scientists do not report how beautiful it is. We report on the losses and changes we observe. 
That is the reason I am so supportive of these "artistic expedions". Someone must remind us how amazing this planet is. This other perspective. 
Thank you for a lovely report from "78".

author: chrisbrown
text: Greenland is changing as we speak. It is losing ice mass every year. This is particularly noticeable at the outlet glaciers where the continental ice cap meets with the fjords in the Labrador Sea. The rate of ice loss that can be seen with the naked eye and primitive markers was the subject of a book by Alfred Wegener, who made a trek across Greenland in the 1920s. His plan was to set up permanent observing stations across southern Greenland to monitor seasonal ice growth and loss.

author: chrisbrown
text: The history of polar exploration is fascinating and the writer of this piece rightly points to the strange distortions national pride brought to the more scientific purpose of many of the attempts to reach the North and South Poles. International cooperation in polar research is much better than these national competitions for vainglory.

author: chrisbrown
text: The history of polar exploration is fascinating and the writer of this piece rightly points to the strange distortions national pride brought to the more scientific purpose of many of the attempts to reach the North and South Poles. The story of the competition between Amundsen and Scott to reach the South Pole is shocking from our present standpoint but it is worth reading just to get an idea of how nationalism can distort scientific discovery. For many years for example the practical and theoretical work of Wegener was belittled and ignored by the British who were the main sponsors of polar expeditions. International cooperation in polar research is much better than these national competitions for vainglory.
